title: smartrappy
text:
Smart reproducible analytical pipeline inspection.



SVG logo of smartrappy


          
  




smartrappy analyses a Python project and infers the directed acyclic graph (DAG) of the code and data dependencies, including the last time any data were refreshed and whether the data exist at all on disk. It is not perfect, and will miss a lot in complex projects: but for simple projects using, say, pd.read_csv(), it does a good job of inferring the steps. It can also infer writing to and from most databases. The inferred DAG is then visualised, and there are several options for doing thatâ€”the default being to produce a visualisation in the terminal.



smartrappy is designed to help you understand the dependencies in a project, especially in a context where there may be a lot of legacy code that resembles tangled spaghetti.



To use smartrappy as a command-line tool:
smartrappy /path/to/your/project
Or to use it within a Python script:
from smartrappy import analyse_project
from smartrappy.reporters import ConsoleReporter


model = analyse_project("/path/to/your/project")
reporter = ConsoleReporter()
reporter.generate_report(model)



To install smartrappy, you can use pip install smartrappy or uv add smartrappy if you are using Astralâ€™s uv. You can also use it as a standalone command-line tool with uv and the uvx command:
uvx smartrappy path/to/your/project



You can find the full documentation for smartrappy at https://aeturrell.github.io/smartrappy/.




smartrappy .


Analysing project at: ../tests/test_set_two

The graphviz and mermaid options are equally as aesthetically pleasing! Head to the docs to see those.





smartrappy [OPTIONS] path/to/your/project




path/to/your/project: Path to the Python project directory to analyse (required)





-o, --output PATH: Output path for the analysis files (without extension)
-f, --format [console|graphviz|mermaid|json]: Output format (default: console)
--all-formats: Generate all output formats. Because why shouldnâ€™t you have it all?
-h, --help: Show help message
--internal: Show only internal code dependencies. (default: false)
--version: Show version information





console: Output in terminal (default)
graphviz: Generate Graphviz visualisation, saved as a PDF
mermaid: Generate Mermaid diagram, which can be embedded in Markdown
json: Generate JSON representation, printed to the terminal if no output path is specified

By default, outputs are stored in the directory from where the smartrappy command is run.




You can find a full list of requirements in the pyproject.toml file.
This package also requires that you have GraphViz installed.



Distributed under the terms of the MIT license, smartrappy is free and open source software.



If you encounter any problems, please file an issue along with a detailed description.

title: smartrappy
text:
#Â Contributing
Thank you for your interest in improving this project. This project is open-source under the MIT license and welcomes contributions in the form of bug reports, feature requests, and pull requests.
Here is a list of important resources for contributors:

title: smartrappy
text:
How to report a bug
Report bugs on the Issue Tracker.
When filing an issue, make sure to answer these questions:

Which operating system and Python version are you using?
Which version of this project are you using?
What did you do?
What did you expect to see?
What did you see instead?

The best way to get your bug fixed is to provide a test case, and/or steps to reproduce the issue.

title: smartrappy
text:
How to request a feature
Request features on the Issue Tracker.

title: smartrappy
section: How to set up your development environment
text:
How to set up your development environment
You need Python and the following tools:

uv
Nox
Make
Quarto

Install the package with the existing development requirements:
$ uv sync --frozen
To also update packages, do not use the --frozen flag.
To build the documentation locally, you will also need Make and Quarto (these are non-Python dependencies).
You can build the docs locally to look at them with make, which runs a command to build the README and then another to build the website which can then be found in docs/_site/. Itâ€™s make clean to remove the existing README.
To publish new docs to GitHub Pages (where the documentation is displayed as web pages), itâ€™s make publishâ€”but only devs with admin rights will be able to execute this.

title: smartrappy
text:
How to test the project
Run the full test suite:
$ uv run nox
List the available Nox sessions:
$ uv run nox --list-sessions
You can also run a specific Nox session. For example, invoke the unit test suite like this:
$ uv run nox --session=tests
Unit tests are located in the tests directory, and are written using the pytest testing framework.
You may need to use, for example, uv run nox to ensure that the tests are run in the right environment.
For the pre-commit checks, use
$ uv run pre-commit run --all-files

title: smartrappy
text:
How to submit changes
Open a pull request to submit changes to this project.
Your pull request needs to meet the following guidelines for acceptance:

The Nox test suite must pass without errors and warnings.
Include unit tests. This project aims to maintain 96% code coverage.
If your changes add functionality, update the documentation accordingly.
Run make to generate the new documentation.
Run the pre-commit suite before committing.

Feel free to submit early, thoughâ€”we can always iterate on this.
To run linting and code formatting checks before committing your change, you need to run the following command:
$ uv run nox --session=pre-commit -- install
It is recommended to open an issue before starting work on anything. This will allow a chance to talk it over with the owners and validate your approach.

title: smartrappy
section: How to create a package release
text:
How to create a package release

Open a new branch with the version name
Change the version in pyproject.toml (you can run uv run version_bumper.py, which has script-level dependencies)
Commit the change with a new version label as the commit message (checking the tests pass)
Head to GitHub and merge into main (again, if the CI works)
Confirm the release draft on GitHub
The automatic release GitHub Action will push to PyPI.

If you ever need distributable files, you can use the uv build command locally.

title: smartrappy
section: How to build the documentation manually and locally
text:
How to build the documentation manually and locally
You shouldnâ€™t need to publish the documentation because thereâ€™s a GitHub action that covers it automatically whenever thereâ€™s a new release. But to upload the documentation manually, itâ€™s

Run make to build the documentation
Run make publish to publish the documentation

title: Function reference
text:
What smartrappyâ€™s functions do



analyse_project
Analyse a project folder and build a comprehensive project model.


ConsoleReporter
Report analysis results to the console.


JsonReporter
Generate a JSON representation of the project model.


MermaidReporter
Generate a Mermaid visualisation of the project model.


GraphvizReporter
Generate a Graphviz visualisation of the project model. Exports as PDF
